channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Free Lunch? Yes, Please. Perl job in Vienna.
item.description: One of the largest product and price comparison platforms in German-speaking countries is on the hunt for a Perl programmer who wants to use their skills to eradicate inflated prices. The successful candidate will relish the chance to join a team that attributes nearly two decades of success to an uncompromising commitment to transparency, objectivity, and quality content.

item.title: Variety is the spice of life! Perl Developer role in Dubai!
item.description: Spice up your 9-to-5 in the playground of the rich and famous. Not content with the status quo, you want to see the world. Explore the narrow alleys of the old city, barter for Baharat in one of the world???s largest spice markets, and spend weekends ankle-deep in powdery white sands???all of this is in reach if you read on for our next big opportunity with a thriving international client in Dubai!

item.title: Not your ordinary town! Perl job in Malaysia!
item.description: New, rapidly growing town? Check. Exciting travel opportunities a short drive from home? Check. Excellent employer in a scenic science park? Check, check, check. Now that you know Cyberjaya checks all your boxes, the only thing left to do is send us an email and let us know you???re ready to put down roots in the Multimedia Super Corridor in Malaysia!

item.title: We aren???t Mal-teasing???this is the Perl job you???ve been waiting for!
item.description: The client is a financial company whose meteoric growth over the last twenty years means that they???re a solid investment for anyone looking to make a change in location for their career. They started with the idea that online trading should be available to all, and from there, they???ve built a company with multiple locations worldwide.This may be the perfect opportunity for you.

item.title: Don???t go chasing waterfalls . . .
item.description: Our client is just as famous as those big-time record producers, but without the terrible reputation. They???re one of the UK???s leading estate agencies, and with over 60 branches, they???ve got what it takes to make you a star (programmer, that is). Their website is scaling the charts, and if you can handle the spotlight, then you might be the senior-level Perl programmer that they want to sign.

item.title: Purdue.pm
item.description: 17:30 September 9, 2020 (America/Indiana (UTC-4:00) (English)

item.title: Gabor self reporting for 2020.08
item.description: I am interested both in measuring the things I did and in trying to measure their impact which, in the end, is the more important thing.

item.title: Facebook poll about a Perl-based web app
item.description: The results from the two groups surprised me a lot. Which just mean I should not make any assumptions.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Perl Tk text widget to be used as a console
item.description: A screencast using Perl Tk. Thanks to supporters via Patreon.

item.title: How to combine arrays to a multi-dimensional array and save them to CSV file
item.description: Based on a question from a reader. Thanks to supporters via Patreon.

item.title: Week 75: Raku Review of task "Largest Rectangle Histogram".
Week 75: Raku Review of task "Coins Sum".
Week 76: Raku Review of task "Prime Sum".
Perl Weekly Challenge #76
item.description: Precise description of Goldbach conjecture and cool implementation of Sieve of Eratosthenes.

item.title: PERL WEEKLY CHALLENGE: WEEK 76
item.description: Shahed blog is always full of Raku magic. This time, I found .sum, cool.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 076
item.description: Simon is so precise in his narration. You can never miss the point.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 76: prime sum and word search
item.description: Roger played with Python once again. I loved his "Prime Sum" explanation, very unique.

item.title: Solving word search puzzles in Perl
item.description: The "Word Search" task was proposed by Neil Bowers himself. So I was expecting some magic from him. I must say he didn't disappoint me. Thanks Neil for the blog.

item.title: Week #076: Prime Sum & Word Search
item.description: Please checkout my fight with the task "Prime Sum" and "Word Search" in Perl and Raku.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 76: my last PWC (for a while)
item.description: Luca, all the best for your eye surgery. Hope everything goes smooth and you regain the sight in both eyes.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 76: Letter Grid
item.description: Laurent skipped "Prime Sum" task because of lack of time. However he did manage to get the "Word Search" task done on time.

item.title: PERL WEEKLY CHALLENGE – 076
item.description: Another cool example of Goldbach conjecture to solve "Prime Sum" task. Even "Word Search" solution is also cool.

item.title: Wear a Wig to Play the Goldbach Variations!
item.description: I would like to confess one thing today, I read Colin's blog not for solution but for story behind the scene.

item.title: Sum of Individuals Gives Meaning - CY's Take on PWC#076
item.description: Cheok-Yin used Goldbach's conjecture to solve "Prime Sum" task. She shared her fight with the other task "Word Search".

item.title: Primal Words with Raku
item.description: Arne blog is once again full of Raku magics. I will revisit sometime next for thorough read.

item.title: Challenge 076
item.description: Welcome on board, Andinus. Congratulation on your first blog for The Weekly Challenge.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 076
item.description: Adam made use of pre-computed Prime Numbers to solve the "Prime Sum" task.

item.title: Raku Review - Perl Weekly Challenge - 075
item.description: Please check out the video review of Raku solutions to the task "Coins Sum" and "Largest Rectangle Histogram" by Andrew Shitov.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 076
item.description: Enjoy quick recap of last week contributions by the Team PWC dealing with the "Prime Sum" and "Word Search" tasks in Perl and Raku. This week check out the unique ways of word search task. I am confident you will be amazed by the quality of solutions by Team PWC.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 077
item.description: Welcome new week with couple of fun tasks "Fibonacci Sum" and "Lonely X". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read FAQ page.

item.title: A concise mtime sorted directory listing application
item.description: Perfect use of Mojolicious::Lite and Mojo::File. Please checkout cool application created with the right tool.

item.title: Learn Enough Git and Github to take part in the Weekly Challenge
item.description: In response to Lady Aleena blog, Dave Cross shared this blog to help her and anyone who wants quick introduction to Git/GitHub.

item.title: Perl 7 – How To Start Preparing To Make The Transition?
item.description: Dana takes us through the preparation of transition to Perl 7.

item.title: Fixing an example in Mojolicious
item.description: Flavio fixed bug he found in a Cookbook for Mojolicious.

item.title: Why I don't try the Perl Weekly Challenges
item.description: Lady Aleena shared her views why she hasn't yet joined the weekly challenge.

item.title: Monthly Report - August
item.description: It is time for monthly report. Time to reflect the month just passed.

item.title: RxPerl release candidate is out
item.description: Karjala announced release candidate v0.16.0 on CPAN.

item.title: CPAN uploads
item.description: Last week there were a total of 209 uploads to CPAN of 131 distinct distributions by 78 different authors. Number of distributions with link to VCS: 94. Number of distros with CI: 38.

item.title: #476 - Migrate to Perl 7
item.description:
Hi there

Recently I came across blog post talking about preparation to Migrate to Perl 7. It is always nice to see ActiveState is showing interest. ActiveState has been the in the forefront when it comes to Perl on Windows imho. I have always kept a copy of ActiveState Perl on my windows box, just in case. Not many books available on Perl 7 except one, Preparing for Perl 7 by brian d foy. It is the best introduction to Perl 7.

Are you looking for introduction to Git/GitHub?

If you say yes then I would highly recommend the latest blog by Dave Cross. Although he doesn't blog very often these days but everytime he does I make sure I don't miss it. There is always something for everyone.

Erki Ferenc, currently maintain and support Rex, the friendly automation framework. He recently shared a blog looking for sponsor. Do you use Rex? If you do then please do become the first sponsor.

Last but not the least, if you are active on Facebook, then do checkout Perl Town Hall every Friday. It is fun to watch Will Braswell live in action every week.

Enjoy rest of the newsletter and don't forget to keep social distancing.
